posts.name: Mihai Nicoara
posts.cooked: So far ive tried to get our robot to drive up to an AprilTag using the Ramsete Command the the poseEstimator. We get the apriltag’s pose from PhotonVision, make a trajectory with that and the robot’s current pose, and then we feed that trajectory into the Ramsete Command. However, I’ve found out that you can’t update the trajectory on the fly. Does anyone have any other ideas how to drive to an apriltag with a differential drive chassis.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: This is for swerve but u should be able to just change the drive controller FRC2023/TestTransform.java at main · Frc5572/FRC2023 · GitHub .

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: Most basic method is to set your rotation based on how far left and right the tag is, and has a set throttle. You can even get fancy and set the throttle based on driver input during teleop!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.cooked:
I think 971 had an algorithm for a similar problem in 2019 (driving to the Rocket using the RR Tape) which might be worth taking a look at. Now that this is being brought up, I’m having trouble finding where I heard them talk about, but I think it was in one of the Spartan Series videos.

6328 also did some form of this during 2022, so you might want to consult that build thread as well. They talk about it in this post - their code is fully open source too.

If On the Fly trajectory generation isn’t working, it might be possible to calculate the radius of curvature between your current pose and the tag and pass that to your drive command.

You can update the trajectory on the fly by killing the command and restarting it, this isn’t a great way to handle it but if you want to stick to using the Ramsete Command built in it’s definitely the easiest way.

posts.name: James Kuszmaul
posts.cooked:
No clue which of our Spartan Series talks we mentioned it in, but our 2019 code for this is in 971-Robot-Code/line_follow_drivetrain.h at master · frc971/971-Robot-Code · GitHub and 971-Robot-Code/line_follow_drivetrain.cc at master · frc971/971-Robot-Code · GitHub

The core goal of that was to let the driver continue to control the velocity of the robot, while automatically controlling the heading of the robot to properly place the hatch panel or cargo ball, and so we created a control loop for the drivetrain that attempted to control to a goal state that was represented as [heading, velocity, angular rate] (with a goal angular rate of zero). Whether that would be desirable this year depends on how your game piece placements works and what parts of the placement process are better to have driver control vs. having automatic control.
